articles.headline: Inflation Is Popping From Sydney to San Francisco. It May Be a Good Sign.
articles.snippet: Inflation has surged across advanced economies. The shared experience underlines that price gains come from temporary drivers — for now.
articles.abstract: Inflation has surged across advanced economies. The shared experience underlines that price gains come from temporary drivers — for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Price gains are shooting higher across many advanced economies as consumer demand, shortages and other pandemic-related factors combine to fuel a burst of inflation.

articles.headline: From Afghanistan to the World Cup, Tiny, Wealthy Qatar Steps Up
articles.snippet: The Gulf state played a major role in the American airlift, the latest evidence of the small but gas-rich country punching above its weight on the world stage.
articles.abstract: The Gulf state played a major role in the American airlift, the latest evidence of the small but gas-rich country punching above its weight on the world stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — As chaos took over the United States’ last-minute efforts to evacuate more than 120,000 of its citizens and partners from Afghanistan last month, a tiny, wealthy country that many Americans would struggle to find on a map suddenly found itself uniquely placed to help out.

articles.headline: Mexico’s Supreme Court Votes to Decriminalize Abortion
articles.snippet: The ruling, which sets a precedent for the legalization of abortion nationwide, follows years of efforts by a growing women’s movement in Mexico.
articles.abstract: The ruling, which sets a precedent for the legalization of abortion nationwide, follows years of efforts by a growing women’s movement in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Criminalizing abortion is unconstitutional, Mexico’s Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday, setting a precedent that could lead to legalization of the procedure across this conservative Catholic country of about 130 million people.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez

articles.headline: Democrats and Lobbyists Gird for Battle Over Far-Reaching Tax Increases
articles.snippet: Congressional committees this week begin drafting tax increases on the wealthy and corporations to pay for a $3.5 trillion social policy bill, but the targets are putting up a fight.
articles.abstract: Congressional committees this week begin drafting tax increases on the wealthy and corporations to pay for a $3.5 trillion social policy bill, but the targets are putting up a fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats always knew their battle plan for raising taxes on corporations, large inheritances and the superwealthy would not survive initial contact with the enemy.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman, Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: If You Never Met Your Co-Workers in Person, Did You Even Work There?
articles.snippet: As the pandemic drags on, more people are beginning and leaving new jobs without once seeing their colleagues face-to-face, leading to an easy-come, easy-go attitude toward workplaces.
articles.abstract: As the pandemic drags on, more people are beginning and leaving new jobs without once seeing their colleagues face-to-face, leading to an easy-come, easy-go attitude toward workplaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kathryn Gregorio joined a nonprofit foundation in Arlington, Va., in April last year, shortly after the pandemic forced many people to work from home. One year and a zillion Zoom calls later, she had still never met any of her colleagues, aside from her boss — which made it easier to quit when a new job came along.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: How Educational Differences Are Widening America’s Political Rift
articles.snippet: College graduates are now a firmly Democratic bloc, and they are shaping the party’s future. Those without degrees, by contrast, have flocked to Republicans.
articles.abstract: College graduates are now a firmly Democratic bloc, and they are shaping the party’s future. Those without degrees, by contrast, have flocked to Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The front lines of America’s cultural clashes have shifted in recent years. A vigorous wave of progressive activism has helped push the country’s culture to the left, inspiring a conservative backlash against everything from “critical race theory” to the supposed cancellation of Dr. Seuss.

articles.headline: Plant-Based Foods Expand, With Consumers Hungry for More
articles.snippet: A broad variety of options are now available in grocery aisles and on restaurant menus, and more companies are looking to get in on the action.
articles.abstract: A broad variety of options are now available in grocery aisles and on restaurant menus, and more companies are looking to get in on the action.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2018, Jenny Goldfarb suddenly had a craving for a corned beef and pastrami sandwich.

articles.headline: Aid Workers Staying in Taliban-Ruled Afghanistan Tread a Tricky Path
articles.snippet: Afghanistan desperately needs aid. Nonprofits desperately want to provide it. But the aid groups are being tested as never before by the uncertainty that has followed the Taliban takeover.
articles.abstract: Afghanistan desperately needs aid. Nonprofits desperately want to provide it. But the aid groups are being tested as never before by the uncertainty that has followed the Taliban takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as American and NATO forces and almost the entire Western diplomatic corps packed up and fled the Afghan capital last month as the Taliban seized control, a handful of international aid directors made a decision: They were staying put.

articles.headline: The Trial of Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes Opens
articles.snippet: A jury will decide whether Ms. Holmes, who founded Theranos and hawked a mission of revolutionizing health care, lied to investors about her company’s technology.
articles.abstract: A jury will decide whether Ms. Holmes, who founded Theranos and hawked a mission of revolutionizing health care, lied to investors about her company’s technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The defendant, wearing a gray suit, sat quietly at a table surrounded by lawyers, her expression hidden behind a blue medical mask. Occasionally, she looked around. Her boyfriend and family members sat, also masked, in the packed gallery of Courtroom 4.

articles.headline: From 4% to 45%: Energy Department Lays Out Ambitious Blueprint for Solar Power
articles.snippet: The department’s analysis provides only a broad outline, and many of the details will be decided by congressional lawmakers.
articles.abstract: The department’s analysis provides only a broad outline, and many of the details will be decided by congressional lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday released a blueprint showing how the nation could move toward producing almost half of its electricity from the sun by 2050 — a potentially big step toward fighting climate change but one that would require vast upgrades to the electric grid.

articles.headline: Your Batteries Are Due for Disruption
articles.snippet: This week, a more efficient type of battery arrives in a wristband fitness tracker. It could soon reach smart glasses, cars and even aircraft.
articles.abstract: This week, a more efficient type of battery arrives in a wristband fitness tracker. It could soon reach smart glasses, cars and even aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALAMEDA, Calif. — The new Whoop fitness tracker straps around the wrist, a lot like any other health monitor or smartwatch. But you can also buy a sports bra or leggings equipped with this tiny device, which can be a sliver of electronics stitched into the fabric of clothes.
